title: 103_s1899
content:
There are no paragraphs provided in the prev_chunk, so I will summarize the curr_chunk directly.

Summarized chunk:
"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." The Augusta Canal National Landmark in Georgia is recognized for its unspoiled areas, excellent water quality, historic landscapes, and significant structures. It connects three national historic districts and two landmarks, creating a culturally rich area. The Augusta Canal connects River, and Meadow Garden, showcasing beautiful rural landscapes, historic cultural sites, and significant undeveloped recreational opportunities. It represents the development of the cotton textile industry in the South and played a key role in the transformation of the agrarian economy into an early industrial economy. Additionally, the area is home to several significant sites associated with American Revolution, Civil War, Native Americans, Colonial Americans, African Americans, Chinese Americans, and Irish. The Augusta Canal area, home to Americans of various backgrounds, is in need of assistance to fully realize its cultural, historical, and recreational potential. The Secretary of the Interior has designated it a priority for protection due to its threatened status. Local agencies and private citizens are eager to collaborate in preserving and enhancing the resources of the Augusta Canal National Historic Landmark. The purpose of this Act is to establish a cooperative management framework for the Augusta Canal in Georgia to retain, enhance, and interpret its significant features while promoting economic development. The Act also establishes the boundaries of the Augusta Canal National Heritage Area. The Augusta Canal National Heritage Area is established in Georgia and South Carolina, including lands known as the Augusta Canal. The boundaries are outlined in the Augusta Canal Master Plan, with a detailed description and map to be published by the Secretary of the Interior. Additionally, the Act establishes the Augusta Canal Commission. The Augusta Canal Commission is established with members appointed from various entities including the Augusta Canal Authority, the mayor of Augusta, Georgia, the Georgia congressional delegation, the Governor of Georgia, and the Governor of South Carolina. The Augusta Canal Commission is established with members appointed from various entities. The Commission shall elect a chairman from among its members, and vacancies will be filled in the manner of the original appointment. The Augusta Canal Commission is established with members appointed from various entities. The Commission shall elect a chairman from among its members, and vacancies will be filled in the manner of the original appointment. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The Augusta Canal Commission must prepare a management plan for the Heritage Area within 1 year of the Act's enactment. The plan should integrate Federal, State, and local plans, including the Augusta Canal Master Plan, for the protection and enhancement of cultural, natural, and recreational resources. The Secretary can offer technical and financial assistance, and must approve the plan within 180 days of submission. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the plan submitted within 180 days. Criteria for approval include strong local support, economic compatibility, effective partnership potential, respect for private property rights, and appropriate action to ensure property rights are upheld. The Augusta Canal Commission must revise and resubmit the management plan if disapproved by the Secretary, who will provide reasons for disapproval and recommendations for revision. The Commission must continue revising and resubmitting the plan until it is approved. Upon approval of the management plan, the Secretary and Augusta Canal Commission will implement it through cooperative agreements for economic development in the area. SEC. 6. ENVIRONMENTAL STANDARDS. This Act does not impose stricter regulations on the Heritage Area than those in place before its establishment. No Federal agency can introduce more stringent regulations solely due to the Heritage Area's creation. SEC. 7. DUTIES OF OTHER FEDERAL ENTITIES. SEC. 7. Duties of other Federal entities include consulting, cooperating, and coordinating activities with the Secretary and Augusta Canal Commission to avoid adverse effects on the Heritage Area. SEC. 8. Authorization of appropriations for carrying out this Act.
